sec.title: Organization of Annex A - Consolidated list of definitions in matrix form
sec.p: The terms/definitions are organized in matrix form in alphabetical order (English language).

caption.p: Columns in the matrix of the consolidated list of ISO/IEC 29187-1 Terms and Definitions

th.style: border-top-style: solid; border-top-width: 3px; border-left-style: solid; border-left-width: 3px;

border-bottom-style: solid; border-bottom-width: 3px; border-left-style: solid; border-left-width: 3px; border-top-style: solid; border-top-width: 3px; border-right-style: solid; border-right-width: 3px;

sec.p:
The primary reason for organizing the columns in this order is to facilitate the addition of equivalent terms/definitions in other languages as added sets of paired columns, (e.g., Spanish, Japanese, German, Russian, Chinese, etc)
See further Part 7 “eBusiness Vocabulary” of ISO/IEC 15944 for an implementation of this approach.

+ The codes representing gender of terms in natural languages are those found in Clause 9.5 “Gender, and official, de facto, or LRL languages”, and especially its Table 1 – “ISO/IEC 20016-1:01 Codes representing grammatical gender in natural languages”;

list-item.p: ISO English, in Column 4, the gender code = “99” since the English language does not have gender in its grammar; and,
ISO French, in Column 7, the gender codes are 01 = masculine, 02 = feminine and 03 = neutre

sec.p: In summary, the use of “G” in Columns (4) and (7) pertain to the “gender” of the term. The English language has no grammatical gender but the French language does. The codes used are as follows:
